Empires & Puzzles Costumed Cao Cao Review: Unstoppable Minion Strategy

The Warlord of Wei returns with a costume that fixes his biggest flaws. With modern stats and the game-changing 'Unstoppable Minions' passive, Costumed Cao Cao transforms from a niche pick into a defensive monster. Find out why his minions are now a nightmare to deal with.
Costumed Cao Cao Review: The Unstoppable Warlord and his Wall of Minions
Costumed Cao Cao, The Unstoppable Warlord: A Wall of Minions

Released in August 2024, the costume for Cao Cao breathes terrifying new life into the Warlord of Wei. While maintaining the core identity of his base form—Slow mana, AoE damage, and dispelling minions—the costume cranks every dial to eleven. With a massive stat overhaul and the addition of the "Unstoppable Minions" passive, Costumed Cao Cao shifts from a dusty relic to a frontline juggernaut, capable of walling off entire teams behind mountains of hit points.

The costume reimagines Cao Cao in an even more imposing, frost-bitten aesthetic. The "Ice-Cold Order" theme is evident in the sharper, crystalline armor and the cold blue gaze. He looks less like a general managing a battle and more like an elemental force of nature. The return of his cape (a point of contention in his original release) adds to the regal, "Warlord" silhouette. It’s a polished, modern look that commands respect.
The difference is night and day. With a base Power of 1108 (compared to the original's 837), Costumed Cao Cao has elite modern stats.

2117 (up from 1468)
These stats allow him to function as a legitimate tank or sturdy flank. With Limit Breaks, his health can push towards 3000, making his minions—which inherit his HP—incredibly difficult to remove.
"Ice-Cold Order" is a masterclass in defensive pressure:
320% to all. While the percentage is slightly lower than the buffed base version, the massive increase in his Attack stat means the
. This is absurd. With a maxed Cao Cao having ~2800 HP, each minion has nearly
. That is like summoning a decent 4-star hero for every ally.
Just like the original, these minions dispel buffs on hit. But because they are so hard to kill, they stick around longer, ensuring the enemy team struggles to keep any buffs active.
A +40% defense buff (up from 30%) for 5 turns makes the already tanky minions and heroes even harder to kill.
If he summons a minion for himself, he effectively gains ~42% extra health. A team of 5 minions adds ~6000 total HP to the board.
With ~1300 Attack (LB2), the minions have ~546 Attack. Five minions slashing a target is equivalent to a strong tile hit every single turn.
The mana generation bonus triggers on minion summon, helping him recharge slightly faster for a second cast.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Kingdom bonus remains a staple, providing small bursts of Mana and Health. Since Cao Cao summons 5 minions at once, this provides a nice immediate injection of resources to the team.
Heroes like Grimble, Ogima, or Captain of Diamonds
. They must be killed by damage.
Bera cannot stop him from summoning.

You cannot silence the minions.
This passive removes 90% of the traditional counters to minion summoners, forcing the enemy to chew through the massive HP pool of the minions with raw damage.

At Level 90, he receives 40% less damage from special skills for 6 turns. This is arguably better than the base version's Regen for a Slow hero. It ensures he survives the initial barrage of fast snipers, guaranteeing he lives long enough to cast "Ice-Cold Order."
The original Cao Cao faded into obscurity. The costume catapulted him straight back to the top of the food chain.
He embodies modern power creep. His stats are top-tier, and his passive specifically counters the heroes that were designed to counter him.

He is a staple in Rush Wars and a very strong contender in standard wars. The combination of high stats, undispellable minion mechanics, and teamwide defense makes him a formidable "Boss" to take down.

This review focuses on the costumed hero.
Comparing back to the base version:
The costume adds +35% Attack, +35% Defense, +45% Health, and +5% Mana via the Costume Bonus alone.
The base version is a support/utility hero. The costume is a
. If he fires, the sheer amount of HP he puts on the board (via minions) usually secures the match.
There is absolutely no reason to run the base version if you have the costume. The "Unstoppable" passive alone is worth the switch, even ignoring the massive stat gains.

Ranger.
This is a shift from the Rogue class of the base. While Dodge (Rogue) is great for survival, Pierce (Ranger) helps his AoE damage cut through defensive buffs.
Maximizes the HP of the minions. Since minion HP is a percentage of the caster's max HP, every point of Health you give Cao Cao makes his "Unstoppable" minions harder to kill.
Sacrifices some of the AoE wipe potential.
Makes the 320% hit sting much more and increases minion attack.
Minions are slightly easier to clear.
. The value of this hero lies in the minions. Making them as fat as possible is the best strategy.
Summoning 42% HP minions that cannot be instantly destroyed creates a massive buffer that most teams cannot break through quickly.
Constant dispel from minions disrupts synergy-heavy enemy teams.
Special Armor (Aether) + High Stats + Defense Buff makes him incredibly hard to kill before he fires.
He is still Slow. If you can kill him before he gathers 12 tiles (or before he fires in Rush), he does nothing.
While his minions are "Unstoppable," certain newer mechanics might still interact favorably against him, though he resists most standard counters.
He doesn't one-shot teams like some modern Slow nukers; he wins by attrition and overwhelming presence.
Absolute God Tier. Firing 42% minions at Very Fast speed is game over.
Excellent tank or flank. The Special Armor protects him early, and once he fires, the attacker is often too far behind to recover.
Great for survivability. The minions protect your squishy heroes from boss hits.
A full Three Kingdoms team with multiple minion summoners. The family bonus ramps up, and the sheer number of minions becomes impossible to manage.
Ludwig next to Cao Cao forces him to fire repeatedly. Two layers of 42% minions are mathematically insurmountable for many teams.
Since you can't "counter" the minions with destroyers, you need raw, high-output damage.
, or other heavy AoE hitters are needed to chew through the meat shield.

(ironically) can steal the buffs the minions provide or interact with them, though she can't destroy them instantly if they are "Unstoppable." (Note: Unstoppable usually prevents removal, stealing might be blocked too).

If you pull this costume, you have won the lottery. Level him immediately. Even at 3/70, his stats will rival maxed 5-stars from older eras. Put him in the center of your defense and watch your trophy count rise.

Costumed Cao Cao is a primary candidate for your Alpha Aethers. The Level 90 power boost and Special Armor passive cover his only real weakness (dying before firing). He is a staple for top-tier War Defense, especially in Rush or Minion wars.
"Just look at those stats... 1118 power without limit breaks? This is ushering in a new age." -
"If your tactic is to use Grimble... forget about it. Cow Cow's minions cannot be destroyed." -
"This guy is a monster... he’s going to make you cry and snap your phone in half." -

Costumed Cao Cao is a perfect example of how a costume can redeem a hero. He goes from being a "has-been" to a "must-have." The combination of Unstoppable Minions and gargantuan stats makes him a defensive powerhouse that demands a specific, high-damage answer. If you don't kill him fast, you will drown in a sea of Wei Soldiers.
A defensive titan and a Rush Attack nightmare. A must-level hero.
